newsitem.title: FRANCE: Election results hit Dassault, Thomson shares.
newsitem.headline: Election results hit Dassault, Thomson shares.

text.p: Shares in aircraft maker Dassault Aviation were suspended limit down on Monday, following a sharp drop at the opening.

Traders said investors feared a surprise lead for the Socialists and left parties in Sunday's first-round parliamentary voting could shoot down a planned merger and privatisation of Dassault and the state-owned Aerospatiale group.
Dassault was suspended with a price floor at 1,112 francs per share. It closed on Friday at 1,230.
Another privatisation-related stock, Thomson-CSF, fell 7.55 percent to 175.20 francs, on the election results.
The conservative government is selling its 58-percent stake in the defence electronics group, which has attracted bidding from conglomerate Lagardere Groupe and engineering group Alcatel Alsthom.

The Socialists have said they do not oppose a pending merger between Dassault and Aerospatiale, which would create an civil and military aircraft giant with annual sales of around 64 billion francs, but would not privatise the new group, as planned. That would constitute a nationalisation of Dassault.

President Jacques Chirac launched last year the Dassault/Aerospatiale merger and Thomson-CSF sale to consolidate France's defence industry, in the face of declining military spending and the lightning-paced moves in the United States.
